C++23: Syntactic Sugar with Deducing This

2023/07/24

The article explores the Curiously Recurring Template Pattern (CRTP), a widely used idiom in C++. The author discusses the benefits of deducing this, a feature introduced in C++23, which simplifies the implementation of CRTP.

CRTP, short for Curiously Recurring Template Pattern, is a technique in which a class called Derived is derived from a class template called Base. The key aspect is that Base takes Derived as a template argument. This pattern is commonly used to achieve static polymorphism, which occurs at compile time without the need for runtime pointer indirection.

In the past, implementing CRTP in C++98 required explicit object parameters. However, with the introduction of deducing this in C++23, the need for explicit parameters is eliminated. The program deducingThisCRTP.cpp demonstrates a C++23-based implementation of CRTP, where the type of the explicit object parameter is deduced to the derived type and perfectly forwarded. This allows for cleaner and more concise code.

The article also briefly mentions the use of deducing this in recursive lambdas. While recursive lambdas can be powerful, the author emphasizes the importance of keeping lambdas concise and self-documenting.

Developers interested in modern C++ and static polymorphism will find the article informative and relevant. The examples provided showcase the evolution of CRTP from C++98 to the upcoming C++23 release. Stay tuned for more updates on C++23 and its new features.
